metadata.title: Dual-mode cross-coupling on aromatic imino compounds by dihydridoruthenium catalysts

Dual-mode cross-coupling on aromatic imino compounds by dihydridoruthenium catalysts Daisuke Hirasawa Yuichi Watanabe Takuma Yamahara Kaku Tanaka Kiyoshi Sato Takamichi Yamagishi ⁎ Division of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Urban Environmental Sciences, Tokyo Metropolitan University, 1-1 Minami-ohsawa, Hachioji, Tokyo 192-0397, Japan Division of Applied Chemistry Graduate School of Urban Environmental Sciences Tokyo Metropolitan University 1-1 Minami-ohsawa Hachioji Tokyo 192-0397 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In the catalytic cross-coupling reaction of ketimines, derived from 1-acetonaphthone or acetophenone derivatives and benzylamine, with trialkoxyvinylsilanes RuH2(PPh3)4 or RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 catalyst caused the selective alkenylation and alkylation on each aromatic ring of the ketimines separately (i.e. dual-mode coupling). Alkenylation occurred at the ortho-position(s) of the benzyl unit and alkylation occurred at the ortho-position(s) of 1-arylethylidene moiety of the substrates. By the stoichiometric reaction of N-1-(4-methylphenyl)ethylidene-4-methylbenzylamine with RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 in the presence of three equivalents of vinylsilane, a novel ruthenium bismetallacylclic complex with two ruthenium-carbon bonds was isolated. This (C,N,C)-bismetallacycle complex was converted to the alkenylated complex by the reaction with two equiv. of vinylsilane. These observations indicate that the dual-mode coupling proceeds in a sequence of alkenylation followed by alkylation via intermediary bismetallacyclic complex formation. Keywords Dual-mode cross-coupling CC bond formation (C,N,C)-bismetallacyclic complex Imines 1 Introduction Carbon-carbon bond formation via activation of CH bond is one of the most important targets in the organic synthetic chemistry from the standpoint of atom economy. Many attempts were made using various transition metal catalysts to realize a variety of synthetic reactions via CH activation [1]. Lewis and Smith reported ortho-selective alkylation by a ruthenium phosphite catalyst in the reaction of phenol and ethylene to give 2-ethyl- or 2,6-diethylphenol in 1986 [2a]. Moore et al. reported α-acylation of pyridine in the reaction with alkene and CO using a low-valent ruthenium catalyst in 1992 [2b]. Murai, Kakiuchi et al. developed a novel CC bond forming reaction (known as Murai reaction) on aromatic ketones [3], esters [4], nitriles [5], imines and imidates [6] with vinylsilanes or alkenes using RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 or Ru3(CO)12 catalysts. In these reactions, ortho CH bond activation is induced by the coordination of a ruthenium center to the functional unit on the aromatic ring and ruthenium hydride species, which is formed by the oxidative addition of low-valent ruthenium to the arene CH bond, adds to a CC bond (hydro-metallation) and following reductive elimination affords ortho-alkylated aromatic compounds [3]. Similar catalytic alkylations were reported using rhodium catalysts [7]. The scope of directing groups on aromatic nuclei was extended to formyl [8], carboxylic acid [9], and heterocycles [10]. Some functional groups (imino or imidate) affect the chemoselectivity in the coupling reaction and a mixture of alkylated product and alkenylated one is formed using an electron-rich vinylsilanes as a coupling reagent [6]. Recently various cationic Ru(II) catalyst systems have been reported to cause selective ortho-alkenylation (dehydrogenative coupling) for aromatics bearing a directing group using simple alkenes or alkyl acrylates as a coupling reagent [11]. Previously, we reported the isomerization of aromatic ketimines, which were derived from aromatic ketones and benzylamine, to aldimine by RuH2(PPh3)4 or RuH2(N2)(PPh3)3 aiming to obtain amino compounds with a chiral carbon. The reaction was performed under a hydrogen atmosphere to increase the turnover of the catalyst [12a]. Under deuterium conditions, an effective H/D exchange was observed at various sites of the imino compounds including ortho positions of the aromatic rings of imines, and that implies the facile activation of ortho CH bonds of the imino compounds [12b]. Therefore, imino unit would be a good candidate for the chelation assisted CC bond formation via activation of the ortho CH bonds. In this study we examined cross-coupling reaction of aromatic imines with vinylsilanes to obtain substituted amines and found that, for N-1-(aryl)ethylidenebenzylamines, coupled alkenylation and alkylation occurred on each aromatic ring separately and selectively (i.e. dual-mode coupling). 2 Experimental 2.1 Substrate preparation and reaction conditions Imino compounds were prepared by two methods A and B. Method A: A mixture of carbonyl and amino compounds was heated at 90 °C in the presence of aluminum oxide [13] and after removing aluminum oxide the imines were purified by recrystallization from hexane as crystals of E- and Z-mixture, or by bulb-to-bulb distillation as oily liquid. Method B: A mixture of carbonyl and amino compounds in benzene was heated in the presence of p-toluenesulfonic acid and after neutralization of acid by sodium carbonate the solution was filtered and evaporated to dryness and the product was purified by recrystallization or by bulb-to-bulb distillation. Typical experimental procedure: A mixture of ketimine 3a (1.5 mmol), triethoxyvinylsilane (7.5 mmol) and ruthenium catalyst RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 (0.03 mmol) in 2 ml toluene in a Schlenk tube was heated under nitrogen at 140° C (bath temp.) for 72 h. After cooling, solvent and silanes were removed in vacuo and the yield was determined by 1H NMR analysis. The product was purified by bulb-to-bulb distillation (250° C/6 mmHg). Coupling product 4a was isolated as yellow oil. In the reaction of ketimines 5a–f, the ratio was as follows: ketimine 5 (0.6 mmol), vinylsilane (6.0 mmol) and ruthenium catalyst (0.03 mmol) in 1.5 ml toluene. The mixture was heated at 140° C for 48–72 h. After removing solvent and silanes, the yield and structure of the products 6a–f were determined by 400 MHz NMR and FAB MS analysis. Complexes A, B and C were prepared under similar conditions. The complex A was prepared as follows: The mixture of RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3, imine 13 and triethoxyvinylsilane in benzene was prepared under nitrogen atmosphere in a Schlenk tube (Ru/imine/silane = 1/3/3) and heated at 70° C for 12 h. After cooling, the reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo and to the residue hexane was added to precipitate the complex. The precipitates were washed with hexane 2 times to give pale yellow powders. The obtained complex was applied to NMR, FAB-MS and IR analysis. Complex B was prepared by the reaction at 110° C for 12 h. NMR spectra were measured in C6D6 or CDCl3 using 400 MHz apparatus. FAB MS analysis was performed in m-nitrobenzyl alcohol(m-NBA) matrix using Xe gas as high energy atom source. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Dual-mode cross-coupling of ketimines We first examined cross-coupling reaction on 1-naphthyl imino compounds derived from 1-formyl- or 1-acetylnaphthalene (Eq. 2) using RuH2(PPh3)4 catalyst. In the reaction of aldimine 1a with triethoxyvinylsilane in toluene at 140° C for 48 h, RuH2(PPh3)4 caused alkylation effectively at the 2-position of the naphthalene ring (2a: 98% yield) similarly to the results reported with naphthalene derivatives having a directing group at 1-position such as carbonyl [3] or cyano unit [5]. For ketimine 1b, too, only 2-alkylated product 2b was obtained in 97% yield under the same conditions. Although coupling at 8-position was reported in the reaction of 1-naphthol with acetylenes by iridium catalyst [14], neither coupling at 8-position of the naphthalene ring nor coupling at the ortho-position of the benzene ring of 1b was observed (Eq. 2). In contrast, in the reaction of ketimine 3a, derived from 1-acetylnaphthalene and benzylamine, with triethoxyvinylsilane in toluene at 140° C, RuH2(PPh3)4 caused a novel coupling reaction, that is, 2-alkylation on the naphthalene ring and ortho-alkenylation on the benzene ring of the benzylamino unit (i.e. dual-mode coupling) (Eq. 3) [15]. The yield of the product 4a was almost quantitative by 72 h reaction at 140° C. For this dual-mode coupling RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 was more effective than RuH2(PPh3)4 (Tables 1 and 2 ), while Ru3(CO)12 or RuH2(PEtPh2)4 was not effective (Table 1). Ru3(CO)12, effective for ortho-alkylation of various compounds [3–5], afforded 2-alkylated products quantitatively, but dual-mode coupling product was obtained only in a trace amount. For Ru(II)-catalyzed alkenylation electron-deficient alkenes such as alkyl acrylates were efficient coupling partners [11], however, ethyl acrylate did not afford any dual-mode coupling product (Table 1, run 7). The dual-mode coupling by dihydrorutehnium catalyst was relatively slow and required larger amount of vinylsilane and relatively higher reaction temperature, compared to the alkylation by the Ru catalysts recently reported [16], which are active even under milder conditions (RT ∼ 70 °C). However, in the presence of 5-equivalent vinylsilane to ketimine 3a the coupling reaction proceeded smoothly. Even at lower conversion the disubstituted product 4a was formed selectively and mono-alkylated or mono-alkenylated products were not observed. In this reaction, formation of dialkylated product was not observed, either. Thus the dual-mode coupling is concluded to proceed consecutively under the reaction conditions examined. In the reaction of the ketimine 5a from acetophenone and benzylamine, more outstanding dual-mode coupling was observed using RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 catalyst. A tetra-substituted product 6a was selectively obtained, that is, double alkenylation occurred on the benzyl unit and double alkylation occurred on the 1-phenylethylidene unit of 5a (Eq. 4) [17]. The possibility that alkylation and alkenylation may occur on the same benzene ring of the compound 5a was denied by the 1H NMR analysis of the product 6a. In the 1H NMR spectrum of the product 6a, two α- and two β-olefinic protons of the two silylethenyl units introduced were observed respectively at 5.87 and 7.43 ppm and the HH COSY spectrum of the ring protons indicated the presence of two sets of one triplet and two doublet signals. Therefore it was concluded that double ortho-alkenylation and double ortho-alkylation occurred separately on each benzene ring. This selective formation of the tetra-substituted product (6a) supports a consecutive character of this dual-mode coupling and the coupling reaction of 5a required higher ratio of vinylsilane to 5a than in the cases of imines 3a. Murai et al. reported the formation of alkenylated product together with alkylated one using vinylsilane for imino or imidate compounds with RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 or Ru3(CO)12 catalyst, however selective ortho-alkenylation was not attained [6]. Recently several systems of Ru(II) catalyst were reported for selective ortho-alkenylation of aromatic ketones, amides or carboxylates with simple alkene or alkyl acrylate [11]. To the best of our knowledge, our system is the first case where alkenylation and alkylation occur separately and selectively on each aromatic ring of the same molecule. The regioselectivity of alkenylation and alkylation was also confirmed by using imino compounds with a methyl group at the ortho-position of the benzylamino unit or of the 1-phenylethylidene moiety (7 and 9). Introduction of a methyl group on the benzyl unit (7) resulted in double ortho-alkylations and mono-ortho-alkenylation (Eq. 5). The presence of a methyl group on the 1-phenylethylidene unit (9) caused mono-ortho-alkylation and double-ortho-alkenylations (Eq. 6). A methoxyl group at ortho-position also suppressed the coupling reaction. In the case of the substrate 11 having methoxyl groups at two ortho-positions of the 1-phenylethylidene moiety, no coupling reaction occurred (Eq. 7). In the reaction of 2-alkylated N-1-(1-naphthyl)ethylidenebenzylamine (12), obtained by the reaction using Ru3(CO)12 catalyst (run 8, Table 1), the substrate remained intact under reaction conditions using RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 (Eq. 8). These results strongly suggest that the present dual-mode coupling is triggered by activation of the ortho-CH bond of the 1-(aryl)ethylidene unit of the imine. 3.2 Isolation of the intermediate complex and its reaction Hiraki et al. reported the formation of a cyclometallated ruthenium hydride complex by the reaction of N-benzylideneaniline with ruthenium complex and vinylsilane [18]. Murai postulated a similar reactive intermediate having a metallacycle structure in the alkylation of aromatic ketones or imino compounds with vinylsilane [3]. Recently, Kakiuchi, Murai et al. reported the formation of an ortho-ruthenated phosphine complex as the active intermediate for ortho-alkylation by the reaction of RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 with vinylsilane [16c]. We tried to isolate an intermediate complex presumably formed in situ by CH activation at the ortho-positions of aromatic rings of imino compounds examined. By the stoichiometric reaction of RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 and ketimine 13 with a molecular formula of C17H19N in the presence of three equivalents of vinylsilane at 70° C, a yellow complex A was isolated. IR and 31P and 1H NMR analyses indicated the presence of CO ligand (ν CO = 1917 cm−1) and two magnetically equivalent PPh3 ligands, and the absence of Ru-H bond in the complex A. 1H NMR spectra also indicated that the ketimine skeleton was retained in the complex. FAB mass data (m/z = 628 [M + 1-PPh3]+) of the complex implies that the formed complex has a molecular formula of Ru(C17H17N)(CO)(PPh3)2. The number of protons of the imine moiety in the complex A diminished by 2 from the original proton number of ketimine 13. HH COSY spectrum of the complex also indicated the presence of three ring protons on each benzene ring (Fig. 1 ). Thus this complex was concluded to have two ruthenium-carbon bonds without Ru-H unit and to be biscyclometallated species in meridional-coordination of the ketimine unit with two phosphines in a trans-disposition [19]. The complex A catalyzed effectively the present dual-mode coupling of compound 13 (140° C, 72 h, 95%) and is considered to be an active intermediate for the coupling reaction. Among the reaction products by stoichiometric reaction of the complex A with two equivalents of trimethoxyvinylsilane in toluene, formation of a monoalkenylated complex and a small amount of dialkenylated complex was observed in FAB-MS analysis (m/z = 773 [M-PPh3]+ and m/z = 921 [M’ + 1-PPh3]+). 1H NMR spectrum also indicated the presence of silylethenyl unit in the complex. It is considered that alkenylation occurred at the ortho position of the benzene ring of the benzyl unit based on the structure of the dual-mode coupling product (Eq. 10). These results suggest the following coupling reaction sequence on the complex: on imino moiety alkenylation occurs first at the benzyl unit followed by alkylation at 1-phenylethylidene moiety of the complex. 3.3 Substituent effect on the coupling reaction of ketimines In order to clarify the character of the biscyclometallated intermediate formation, substituent effects on the reaction of dual-mode coupling were examined for ketimines 3a-e using RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 and dual-mode coupling was commonly observed for compounds examined. As shown in Table 2, introduction of an electron-donating group into the benzyl unit accelerated the coupling, while the presence of an electron-donating group on the naphthylethylidene moiety retarded the reaction. Similar substituent effects were also observed in the reaction of ketimines 5a-f from acetophenone derivatives (Table 3 ). The observed substituent effects strongly suggest the different character of the two CH activation steps at ortho-sites of the aromatic rings. It will be plausible that the oxidative addition by the low-valent ruthenium occurs first at the CH activation step of 1-phenylethylidene unit and the formed Ru(II)-H species will secondly activate the ortho-CH bond of the benzyl unit by electrophilic substitution or concerted metallation deprotonation [1b] to result in the formation of the bismetallacycle complex after dehydrogenation (Scheme 1 ). We tried to show the graphical Hammett-like plot assuming that the yield ratio yR/yH at 24 h reaction or 48 h reaction will correspond to the ratio of kinetic coefficient k R/k H of the coupling reaction. In these “quasi” Hammett plots, using sigma values σm, the sign of apparent ρ-values was opposite for substituents on arylethylidene unit and benzyl unit (Fig. 2 ). This tendency was very distinct in the case of the 1-naphthylethylidene-N-benzylamine derivatives. The sign of apparent ρ values indicate that CH activation on the arylethylidene unit is nucleophilic (ρ > 0, Fig 2B, D) and CH activation on the benzyl unit is electrophilic reaction by Ru complex (ρ < 0, Figs 2A, C). On the bismetallacycle intermediate, carbometallation occurs to the coordinated vinylsilane and β-hydrogen elimination donates alkenylated unit and Ru(II)-H species again, then the formed Ru(II)-H species will activate the residual ortho CH bond of the benzyl unit to afford mono-alkenylated complex without RuH bond. Coordination of vinylsilane to Ru(II) site, carbometallation and β-hydrogen elimination will donate bis-alkenylated benzyl unit and Ru(II)-H species. Two cycles of hydrometallation and reductive elimination will finally afford doubly alkenylated and doubly alkylated product and Ru(0) species. In the present dual-mode coupling reaction using triethoxyvinylsilane, formation of ethyltriethoxysilane was observed to indicate that vinylsilane serves to convert ruthenium-hydride species formed in situ to low-valent ruthenium. 3.4 Reaction of aldimine compound We also examined the cross-coupling reaction of the aldimine 14, isomer of the ketimine 5a, with vinylsilane by RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 catalyst at 140° C, for 72 h (aldimine/vinylsilane/Ru cat. = 20/200/1), and doubly alkenylated and doubly alkylated product 15 was also obtained, though in a lower yield (18%). 1H NMR analysis of the product 15 indicated that the aldimine skeleton was retained and the olefinic protons of two introduced silylethenyl units were observed in lower magnetic field (6.11 and 7.68 ppm) than those of the product 6a (5.87 and 7.43 ppm) from ketimine 5a [17,20]. It implies that the silylethenyl units are in conjugation with the CN bond and it is concluded that the regioselectivity of the coupling was inversed, that is, alkenylation occurred on the benzylidene moiety and alkylation on the (1-phenyl)ethylamine moiety (Eq. 11). In order to obtain the information of this regioselectivity inversion, we tried to isolate the intermediate complex by the stoichiometric reaction of RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 with aldimine 16 (3 equiv.) and vinylsilane (3 equiv.) at 110° C in toluene and obtained another (C,N,C)-biscyclometallated complex (complex B) with a same composition as that of the complex A. In the 1H NMR spectra of the complex B, the signal of methyl protons at 0.56 ppm was observed as a doublet coupled with adjacent methine proton and it indicates that the starting aldimine skeleton was also preserved in the complex. Two phosphines coordinated were observed as double doublet in 31P NMR suggesting a cis-disposition of two phosphine ligands. The stretching vibration of CO ligand was observed at 1822 cm−1, which was much lower than that of the complex A (1917 cm−1). As candidates of the structure of the complex, we postulated two possible structures of the complex, that is, a structure of meridional ligation by the imime 15 and a structure of facial ligation by the imine (Eq. 12) based on the NMR (1H, 31P) spectra and HH COSY spectrum and IR analysis of the complex. The HH COSY spectrum of the complex indicated that three aromatic protons are present on each benzene ring and the formation of (C,N,C)-biscyclometallated complex with two Ru-carbon bonds was concluded. It was to be noted that one aromatic proton (Ha) of the complex B was observed in much higher magnetic field than that of the complex A [19,21]. It is difficult to determine the structure of the complex B since there are several observations which can not be explained by one complex structure. Meridional ligation can explain the lower wavenumber of the CO ligand compared to that of the complex A [19,21], while facial ligation may explain the much higher magnetic field shift of aromatic CH proton (Ha) as shown in the HH COSY spectrum in Fig. 3 . As described above, the structure of the intermediate biscyclometallated complex B was different from that of the complex A, however the exact structure of the complex is not determined at present. Future study will assess the determination of the exact structure of the complex B formed in situ and the elucidation of the reason of regioselectivity inversion in the dual-mode coupling of aldimine 16 based on the structure of the complex clarified. We further examined the coupling reaction of the ketimine Ph(Me)CNCH(Me)Ph 17 having two methyl groups to understand the effect of methyl substituent on the methylene unit of benzyl group in aldimine 14 on the coupling reaction (Eq. 13). Although FAB MS analysis of the product indicated the formation of doubly alkenylated and doubly alkylated product (m/z = 980 [M + 1]+) in a low yield (ca. 15%) along with doubly alkenylated and monoalkylated product (m/z = 790 [M’ + 1]+), the 1H NMR of the reaction product showed complex olefinic proton signals around 5.7 ∼ 6.2 ppm indicating that dual-mode coupling product was a mixture of products of various structures with low regioselectvitiy of alkenylation and alkylation. It seems that the presence of a methyl group on the methylene unit of the benzyl group strongly affects or disturbs the regioselectivity of alkenylation and alkylation. As indicated in Eqs. 7 and 8, blocking of ortho CH activation on arylethylidene unit totally suppressed the observed cross-coupling reaction. We suppressed the presence of ortho-CH at the opposite aromatic ring using 4-Me-C6H4 CHNC(CH3)3 18 and 2-Me-C6H4 CHNC(CH3)3 20 and examined the cross-coupling under the similar conditions (Eqs. 14 and 15). In the reaction of compound 18 the reaction product was a complex mixture of alkylated or alkenylated compounds and the ratio of alkenylation was not high although dual-mode coupling product 19c [23] was formed as one component (Eq. 14). The compound 20 having one ortho-CH unit gave a similar tendency to afford low selectivity of alkenylation [6]. The aldimine 18 afforded a (C,N)-monometallacyclic Ru-H complex (Complex C, Ru-H: δ = -12.75 ppm, triplet, J = 25.6 Hz) by the stoichiometric reaction with RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 and the structure with a trans-disposition of two PPh3 ligands was estimated by HH COSY, 1H and 31P NMR spectra of the complex [22] though some ambiguity is present concerning the position of hydrido and carbonyl ligands (Fig. 4 ) [18]. In these imino compounds, the reaction mechanism via monometallacyclic intermediate is considered to be different from that via (C,C,N)-bismetallacyclic intermediate described so far. The selectivity of alkylation/alkenylation will be controlled by the ease of hydrometallation or carbometallation on the (C,N)-metallacyclic Ru-H intermediate coordinated by vinylsilane. The reaction conditions to realize the selective dual-mode coupling on the same aromatic ring of imino compounds should be searched in future. 4 Conclusion In the reaction of ketimines derived from arylalkylketones and benzylamine with vinylsilanes using dihydridoruthenium catalysts, a novel dual-mode coupling reaction, alkenylation on one aromatic ring and alkylation on another aromatic ring, was discovered. Alkenylation followed by alkylation proceeded consecutively on the ruthenium biscyclometallated intermediate formed in situ and the presence of electron-donating substituent on the benzyl unit facilitated the reaction while electron-donating group(s) in the 1-arylethylidene unit retarded the reaction indicating the different character of the two CH activation steps on two aromatic rings. In the coupling reaction of aldimine 16, isomer of ketimine 5, dual-mode coupling was also observed with regioselectivity inversion. [22] Spectral data of complex C:1H NMR (400 MHz, C6D6) δ = -12.75 (1H, t, J = 25.6 Hz, Ru-H), 1.09(9H, s, C(CH3), 1.72 (3H, s, CH3-C6), 6.31 (1H, s, C6H), 6.69 (1H, d, J = 7.6 Hz, C6H), 6. 95–7.03 (18H, m, PPh3), 7.18 (1H, d, J = 7.6 Hz, C6H), 7. 49–7.52 (12H, m, PPh3), 7.94 (1H, s, CH3PhC(H) = N). 31P{1H}NMR (162 MHz, C6D6, rt) δ = 50.23 (1P, s, PPh3). [23] Spectral data of19c:1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 0. 87–0.94 (2H, m, CH2CH 2Si), 1.21(9H, t, J = 7 Hz, Si(OCH2CH 3)3), 1.23 (9H, t, J = 7 Hz, Si(OCH2CH 3)3), 1.35 (9H, s, C(CH3)3), 2.32 (3H, s, CH 3C6H2), 2. 72–2.77 (2H, m, CH 2CH2Si), 3.80 (6H, q, J = 7 Hz, Si(OCH 2CH3)3), 3.83 (6H, q, J = 7 Hz, Si(OCH 2CH3)3), 6.00 (1H, d, J = 19 Hz, CHCHSi), 6. 87–7.77 (2H, m, C6H2), 7.53 (1H, d, J = 19 Hz, CHCHSi), 8.60 (1H, s, Ar-CHN-).

coredata.dc:description: In the catalytic cross-coupling reaction of ketimines, derived from 1-acetonaphthone or acetophenone derivatives and benzylamine, with trialkoxyvinylsilanes RuH2(PPh3)4 or RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 catalyst caused the selective alkenylation and alkylation on each aromatic ring of the ketimines separately (i.e. dual-mode coupling). Alkenylation occurred at the ortho-position(s) of the benzyl unit and alkylation occurred at the ortho-position(s) of 1-arylethylidene moiety of the substrates. By the stoichiometric reaction of N-1-(4-methylphenyl)ethylidene-4-methylbenzylamine with RuH2(CO)(PPh3)3 in the presence of three equivalents of vinylsilane, a novel ruthenium bismetallacylclic complex with two ruthenium-carbon bonds was isolated. This (C,N,C)-bismetallacycle complex was converted to the alkenylated complex by the reaction with two equiv. of vinylsilane. These observations indicate that the dual-mode coupling proceeds in a sequence of alkenylation followed by alkylation via intermediary bismetallacyclic complex formation.
coredata.dc:title: Dual-mode cross-coupling on aromatic imino compounds by dihydridoruthenium catalysts
